intro: Papaver lapponicum subsp. lapponicum, commonly known as the Lapland poppy, is a herbaceous perennial native to Arctic and alpine regions of Europe and Asia. It produces striking, bright red, cup-shaped flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has smooth, often hairy stems and lance-shaped, dark green leaves that are arranged alternately along the stem. Its flowers are typically 2–5 cm in diameter and are surrounded by a prominent, saucer-shaped calyx. This species is adapted to cold climates and is often found in rocky or sandy soils.
